Authors: S. I. Warwick, Connie A Sauder, Ihsan Al-Shehbaz
Title:
Plant Genome Biodiversity and Evolution Volume 1, Part C.
Phanerogams.
Abstract:
The genus Sisymbrium L. as currently circumscribed
includes about 95 species, of which 41 are distributed in the Old World
and 54 in the New World. Sisymbrium has been variously delimited, with
several segregate genera proposed (subtribe Sisymbriinae) primarily for
the New World taxa. Phylogenetic studies using nuclear ribosomal ITS and
chloroplast trnL-F sequences, have assessed proposed evolutionary
relationships and taxonomic limits of Old and New World Sisymbrium, its
segregate genera, and their affinities to the tribe Thelypodieae. ITS
sequence data indicated a polyphyletic origin for Sisymbrium and did not
correspond well to Schulzs sectional classification. Two species belong
to the tribe Brassiceae, and the remaining Sisymbrium species fall into
two major clades: Old World (including the Middle Eastern S. acueolatum
and S. afghanicum and North American S. linifolium), and the New World
Sisymbrium herein assigned to the Thelypodieae alliance. The latter
alliance is also well differentiated from the Old World species
cytologically and morphologically. Therefore, as delimited herein, the
genus Sisymbrium is almost exclusively restricted to the Old World. The
New World species previously recognized in Sisymbrium (e.g.,
Mostacillastrum, Coelophragmus, Werdermannia, Schoenocrambe (two spp.)),
as well as Sibara and Pringlea, form part of the Thelypodieae
alliance.
